author: CyberConnoisseur
body:
I'm aware what Check Points are.  I actually own SMB versions of all 3 vendors.  Palo, Fortinet, Checkpoint, all do the same NGFW stuff - IPS/Content Inspection, DNS Security, Decryption, etc...  All of these features are being disrupted by cloud-native products like Cloudflare, Zscaler, and cloud providers like AWS/Azure.

The "cloud" sentiment is happening whether its your thing or not.  The biggest companies on earth are abandoning their data centers.  It is simply more cost and risk effective.  Will it happen tomorrow? No. But it is a fact that pure cloud is going to be the dominant way IT departments function in the future.  We'll see "hybrid cloud" for a while, but it wont last.  


Regulatory and compliance requirements are changing regulations to accommodate cloud only environments as everyone agrees this is the way forward.  


I don't think that Checkpoint is a *bad* investment.  I just don't see any explosive growth potential coming from them long term.  As others have said, r/wallstreetbets is for rapid tenderloin accumulation.

Disclaimer:  ***Not a financial advisor or anything of the sort. This is not investment advice.***

author: mimik987
body:
Hey there, this is Tom, this is one of my accounts, not sure which as I tend to lose passwords and end up making new accounts... :). I just finished reading this post and I want to stress I have no hate or anger towards the OP, but I'd like to offer my side of story if you may:

1. I think the OP should have disclosed he is managing a competing youtube channel in the same niche as me. Its a smaller channel and it is pretty much the same content and audience. Not saying he did this to clout chase, as I am sure his motives are pure, but he needed to disclose this fact and omitting it is kinda weird... (especially since he posted this exact post in multiple YouTube promotion groups...)
2. He couldn't find my intro video after viewing it once: That is because it will only auto play for first time visitors, for repeat visitors the page plays the recent video posted instead of the intro. That point amused me...
3. I only do small cap stocks and trendy stocks: here is an excel spreadsheet which I keep of every stock I covered, Its open to my subscribers to audit me at any moment. You will soon find out I cover large cap blue chip stocks (apart from 2 stocks) like CRM, MSFT, ORCL, FTNT, TSLA, TWLO and many others. [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bR4KloyKmRXqY-Eh2nG-fs4-yRqDpfnkTpCYIgh1Q3E/edit#gid=0](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bR4KloyKmRXqY-Eh2nG-fs4-yRqDpfnkTpCYIgh1Q3E/edit#gid=0)
4. He couldn’t find my credentials on social media: I’ve said this many times before that Tom Nash is a stage name, I am a Russian guy and this name is not my legal name. Exposing this seems to me a bit strange after I made a video explaining that months ago. My real social media is obviously not under this name and since I want to keep my privacy I won’t disclose it ever. I want to protect my own identity. I got a family and kids so I think most of you would agree that is the smart move. Saying my credentials don't show up on my fake profile on linkedin is kinda funny...
5. I did other youtube channels, including gaming, audio and youtube education: My youtube passion is not something new, I was doing youtube for years, including educational content and even an audio channel. I could have deleted these old channels but I keep them up since its NOT a secret lol. One channel is called gearly reviews and we posted once every few months. We actually have a few videos that got millions of views there and I’m proud of that channel. Which I wish I had more time to work on. My youtube educational videos are mostly gone now since it’s trash but some can be found here and there and they are cringe. I do still run a youtube group for creators and I posted about it many times on my channel asking people to join if they want to do youtube. It’s sponsored by TubeBuddy and we plan to revive it and post much more content there to help creators. I always did youtube on the side as a hobby and obviously I was trying to find my audience and become a full time YouTube, this was always my dream and exposing this item is kinda pointless. I even had a gaming channel called gamernomics but it’s gone now since I feel I was so cringe. I’m still a massive gamer though even with 3 kids... for me saying I was always passionate about youtube and using the fact I tried to break through as proof I’m a fraud is strange lol. Funny enough I only broke through when I quit my job and went all in on this channel without a safety net.
6. My guru exposed videos: I loved doing guru exposed videos but I kinda shifted away from this since it’s very taxing emotionally being negative and going at people. When I moved into the stock scene it wasn’t as big and in fact my views took a hit. My Ignite and NKLA videos used to get massive views which my stock videos will never get but I love it so I’ll keep doing it. It’s true I have no courses or affiliate links on my channel but I do have channel membership and a big Patreon community, since I am trying to make it into a viable business, don’t think there is something wrong here.
7. As far as work, and what I did. It’s very simple. After graduating from Umich I was lucky to even find a job in 2009. Started as an intern at a major investment bank for 40k per year and moved my way up. Eventually moved up to senior analyst. Never claimed I was managing director or a VP or a stock broker lol. I then moved back to my country and got a job at one of the BIG4 companies (EY, PWC, DTT, KPMG). Just so you know every big4 has a multiple divisions and I ended up working for the financial division doing valuations, due diligence and a lot of transnational work related to M&A. My job was to look at financials and find out how valuable the company really is. Eventually burned out and quit to decide to go in on YT and here we are.

No hate from me to the OP. It’s all good. Much love Tom.

author: CadperGN
body:
Thanks for this addition.

I guess the buzzword for vendor is depending on where you look as all I hear is that the management interface and the distribution of ruleset is so much better on the Check Point gear. That said Check Point is not only a firewall. It's an IPS blade with a firewall. Something (some of) the others charge extra for.

The sentiment for "all cloud" is not my thing. I don't believe in cloud-only for a cross-sector and industry as the replacement for on-prem. Cloud may work on a broad scale for some industries and sectors but I recon we'll see more agnostic and hybrid environments being the norm when we're done buzzwording (as if that ever happens in infosec lol). At some point in time regulation may follow but some things simply don't work well in the cloud (legislation and other outside factors).

About IaC, I see Check Point being much more on-par than for example Cisco. I haven't worked with Fortinet or Palo Alto although we had a sales meeting with Palo Alto for some of the "Next Gen Slideware" they had which I (personal preference) did not like at all. I really do believe that the government wide investment into Cyber Security that Isreal has made will benefit the vendors from there. Cyberark may also be one to benefit although they are far to expensive for my liking atm.

About Fortinet. I haven't had time to proper dig into them yet but the fundamentals python code I've got really have them as a candidate for a rocket in price.

I'm glad to see a fellow Security-person here :-)

author: VegetableInterest4
body:
The tech sector is in a shit spot now. Explains why it has an even worse downturn. PLTR had a sell volume of 69M today at market open.

PLTR might still be dropping until about 21 or 20 maximum imo. 

I hope it recovers though. It is a cybersecurity company that worked on US government military contracts and with the CIA, recently had a contract with IBM but IBM had a garbage last report (with the pervious ones also being bad) also, so I do not see much +++ in the following 1-2 weeks. After that it might get better I hope.

In the long run/big picture a tech company is always a good investment unless their employees are completely braindead. I wouldn't say they are so stupid in this example since they have worked with the military and they should not be lenient work partners imo.

The behavior pattern I have noticed with PLTR is that when all the other stocks are doing poor PLTR is still doing well or it is sometimes Workhorse GRP, the traders need something to fill their daily trades even on red days.

Those days are mostly just up and down jumps and lots of short selling on a 1-5 minute time range.

They did unlock the stock from the IPO either today or it might be on Friday, not sure about this information though. 

Any time a "hack" attack happens or similar security breach, this stock also tends to have a somewhat of a rising. Similar with other companies for cybersecurity like Fortinet, Qualys and Splunk.

In general I would say to stay away from this until late evening Friday 21:55 and then buy and hope for next Monday market opener to be a better restart.

Non legally binding advice.

I do own the stock.

author: StopDeleteMyAccount
body:
I think you underestimated the importance of TSMC. Just think about how many things today's use chips, TVs, cars, computer, data center, phones, cameras. About half of them are from TSMC (based on market share). Now apply the current auto ICs shortage to every sector. That's what will happen if China invades Taiwan. We are not going to see a collapse of TSM, we are going to see a Great Depression. I dont think the western powers will allow that to happen.

Also the fact that TSMC is the largest fab and has the most capacity but is still at full capacity tells you the world needs IC. Apple, AMD along takes away so much of their 5nm and 7nm slot already. The fact that Nvidia didn't produce their rtx3000s in TSMC is actually bullish because TSMC couldn't care less about it to lower its price to compete with Samsung. 

On the topic of Samsung, their fab is the only threat to TSMC. However, it has been shown from time to time that TSMC process is better, in terms of performance and power. Apple once used both TSMC and Samsung to produce one of their iPhone processor. You can Google the result, but basically TSMC wins in every metrics.

Intel on the other hand, is a closed fab meaning they do not produce chips for other companies. They only make their own stuff. So even they figure out their 7nm, it is not a threat to TSMC. On top of that there is no capacity in TSMC for Intel (said TSMC). 

There are many other fabs in Taiwan outside of TSMC. And they are all getting the benefit from TSMC being at full capacity. It will be interesting to see if they can take all those orders in and grow or TSMC will increase its capacity faster.

Other ealier concern is China. It is spending a lot of resources in chip manufacturing. However, this is no long a issue because of US sanctions. ASML and other key equipment manufacturers are not allowed or limited to sell to China. This basically put a chock hold on Chinese fans. Unless they can develop their own equipment, there is no chance for them to catch up to Samsung or TSMC.


This is my two cents. I'm increasing my holdings whenever I can on a 2~3% dip day. I don't see any competition in the next 5~10 years minimum.


TLDR: This world need ICs. TSMC has 55% share in it. So you want in then buy TSMC. This is not going to fall into the hand of China, or there will be greater concern than TSMC share price.

author: Mezmorizor
body:
This is probably going to be a fairly long post, so I'm going to preface it by saying I'm not a financial adviser and have no non ETF semiconductor holdings. I work in a field that has semiconductor companies as a pipeline, so I have talked to senior manufacturing managers and know some tool owners (mostly intel fwiw) which theoretically gives me an above average understanding of how a CPU goes from design to market. As far as I know everything I'm about to say is publicly available, but if this post disappears on you...I was probably wrong on that. Do your own research before making a decision either way.

tl;dr, no. AMD is likely overvalued because people don't understand how the semiconductor industry works.

The first thing to note is that AMD already has a lot of growth built into its price with a P/E of ~80. I do think AMD will grow, their leadership appears competent and the job postings I see on linkedin are what I'd want to see from a semiconductor manufacturer trying to grow, but 80 is a lot.

I've seen a lot of people just assume that AMD has a technology lead over intel because they won this generation, but that's just incorrect. Intel has a much more challenging process that requires significantly more manufacturing know how to actually produce economically. Intel is still best in the world by a lot when it comes to actually working on silicon. One bad process generation where AMD's safer approach won out doesn't change that. Maybe we can revisit this in a decade, but for now I'm not putting much thought into one data point.

Speaking of generations, this is a long term industry where at any given moment you are working on 3 different process generations (at least that's how intel does it. I assume others are similar). One market team, one industrial development team (one generation out), and one design team (two generations out). The industrial development team moves to the market team when the generation they developed comes to market, and the market team becomes the industrial development team. The design team doesn't actually work on real silicon, so they're always two generations out. Presumably intel will largely not be retaining a relatively large portion of this current team, but either way it'll take quite a while to see what the true effects are because the semiconductor industry is hardware and hardware is slow+hard.

Also keep in mind that each process generation is kind of radically different from each other. Some parts remain the same, eg an argon plasma surface treatment will probably be a step in the next process generation too, but R&D is still the best predictor of future success in this field and intel simply spends a lot more than AMD does.

author: SneakyQuant
body:
•             Amid the heavy de-grossing activity occurring street-wide, funds reduced short exposure significantly on single stocks with a focus on highly volatile equities and equities with high levels of short interest. However, short exposure on equity Index ETF’s was relatively flat to slightly higher as funds stayed in broader hedges (SPY and QQQ rose while IWM was net covered). Calls for shorting being “dead” may be overstated as many funds are actively watching the highly speculative names for signs of exhaustion and opportunities to put short positions back on.

•             Other ETF’s: We saw short interest increase on high yield and govt. debt ETF’s: HYG, IEF, AGG, and LQD. Metals - SLV (also heavily mentioned on retail blogs), GDX and GLD, are all being covered. ARKK SI has been rising as Cathie Woods ETF’s continue to see inflows. XRT borrow is in high demand as GME’s weighting ballooned recently. However, large redemptions has caused borrow liquidity to completely dry up.

•             Reddit names: GME short Interest declined by \~40% -60% on a share basis and remains in the range of 65% - 85% of the float. We are beginning to see an uptick in demand and intraday shorting activity. Borrow is available and rates are currently easing. AMC and BBBY are seeing a similar approach while shorts positions were added to BB and NOK. Any near term weakness on these high flyers may result in further buying pressure from remaining shorts.

•             Not everything was covered: DUK, WISH, TFC, APD, FIS, CCL, VIR, NOC, STZ, PLAN, DG and INTC all saw moderate shorting activity.

•             REIT’s – SI rising in this space – SUI, EXR, EQIX all saw material shorting.

author: selitos
body: When I got my first job out of college in 2010 I put $500 into the market just to see how to do it and chose INTC because I liked their processors. I freaked out because $500 was a lot of money at the time so I pulled it out after a couple weeks and didn't return to the market until my company started giving me RSUs years later. Point of the story is I should've left it in. Not only has the price gone up 3x, but I missed out on the dividends. It was never a gamble either because I picked an established company in a healthy sector. What'd I spend the money on instead? Weed and beer?  For your early positions just invest in a company and sector you believe in, that is established and has a great product.

author: anakhizer
body:
Intel is all that yes.

But they are also for the last several years:
1. In deep trouble with manufacturing -10nm fiasco and on top of that, 7nm is similarly in a very bad place
2. Lacking a competitor to AMDs chiplets which are the key in profitable CPU manufacturing.
3. TSMC is soon 2 nodes ahead of Intel as their 5nm process is already shipping for Apple and their resources see much higher than Intel's.
4. Intel has been wasting a lot of money on stock buybacks last few years.
5. Leadership problems, rumors of infighting etc

Anyway, there are surely more, my point was that every sign points to AMD having a unique opportunity to win much more of the market - and if it happens that Intel can catch up, great, but it will not happen at least u. The next 2-3 years imho.

author: c00750ny3h
body:
I am erring on the side of caution with Intel.

Since the rapid drop in Intel's price due to the announced delays, the basis for Intel's stock moving up seems to be the claims of planning to outsource production to TSMC for advanced node CPUs, as confirmed by their new CEO and at the request of the Third Point CEO.  However, it makes no technical sense to me.

TSMC is already overbooked for their 7nm and 5nm fabs.  They have many loyal long time high paying customers, Qualcomm, Apple, Nvidia, AMD and there is no way TSMC would delay their orders to accommodate Intel.  To increase fab capacity to accommodate Intel's core i7 and i9 lineup would require a wafer production increase by around 33 to 40% which is could require more than 50 billion dollars worth of additional factory equipment.  TSMC wouldn't risk fab spending for Intel if there was even the slightest remote risk that Intel would go back to producing their own processors in the future.  In contrast, there is absolutely no chance that Apple, Nvidia, Qualcomm will start producing their own chips and end their business with TSMC.
